Definition: In this task, u-l b shown a sentence, and u should determine whether it is overruling or non-overruling. In law, an overruling sentence is a statement that nullifies a previous case decision as a precedent by a constitutionally valid statute or a decision by da same or higher ranking court which establishes a different rule on da point of law involved.

Positive Examples.input: we therefore reverse the order denying the motion to suppress and recede from any language in moskowitz which could be interpreted contrary to our holding in this case.
Positive Examples.explanation: The word "disapprove" shows that cooper and craven case isn't valid anymore and it's a overruling sentence.

Positive Examples.input: qualified immunity protects ""all but the plainly incompetent or those who knowingly violate the law.""
Positive Examples.explanation: It's a good example. This sentence doesn't overrule any law, So it's non-overruling.

Negative Examples.input: the language to the contrary in perez is disapproved.
Negative Examples.explanation: This sentence doesn't overrule any rule, So it is incorrect.

Negative Examples.input: the superior court reasoned that four justices in l.b.m. would have permitted the gal to represent the child in the tpr hearing when the child's best interests and legal interests did not conflict.
Negative Examples.explanation: This sentence disapproves the decisions of the fourth district, So It's overruling.

the third and fifth district courts of appeal have concluded, consistent with the first district, that miller is not retroactive, while the second and fourth district courts of appeal have held, to the contrary, that it is.

wilson was disapproved on other grounds in kellett v. superior court (1966) 63 cal.2d 822, 827 [ 48 cal.rptr. 366, 409 p.2d 206], but the court in kellett nonetheless agreed that the flight from the officer constituted a separate offense from the procurement and threatened use of the gun.
we also disapprove the language from hilton suggesting that an offer of proof must vouch for the anticipated testimony.
the court of appeals panel erred in anderson, and we overrule that decision.

see also figgins v. cochrane, 403 md. 392, 409 (2008) (""if any competent material evidence exists in support of the trial court's factual findings, those findings cannot be held to be clearly erroneous."")
